title: @Riot: want to make support better? Do something about sightstone.
body: If you want to know where to start in trying to make support a better role, start there. Start by giving us a little agency for doing what we want, because I'm really sick of being a ward bot and wasting 800g on an item that doesn't improve my champ in any way except a pittance of hp.

Well. every person can have up to 3 wards. Trinket puts out 60-120 (depending on lvl) sec Wards opposed to Tracking Smite and Sightstone put down 150 sec wards at all lvls.

Vision is valuable, Sightstone prolly need a QoL buff, but they are needed.

Second, no items slots for wards late game. Even the supports get screwed by that. ESPECIALLY the supports get screwed by that.

The only way to make that happen is if vision was completely uniform. Basically in a position where neither gold nor experience, can really change the effectiveness of vision. But as long as one person can buy into the vision game, it's going to continue to remain lopsided. You would have to remove sight stone, (and the eye items), the tracker's knife, and perhaps even the control wards from the shop, and rely exclusively on trinkets. 

Most of the other changes to the vision game are predominantly Jungle focused. First we had the Scuttler, then the Raptor smite buff, Now we have a vision plant. Mechanics like these could work when it doesn't require people to invest in a particular way. (Except you have to play around them and treat them as a miniature objective. )

I am well aware that vision is important and powerful. That is not my issue. My issue is that it is almost all loaded on an item that is forced to purchase every game, and on the player with the least amount of gold that already spends their gold mostly on helping there team as is.

Sightstone exists as a vision gate, and nothing more. And its prevalence is moreso a check system for riot to balance vision than anythign else.

Its archaic design.

but they have tried to change that with free trinkets which no one uses outside of laning phase... and trackers knife which no jungler gets

so whats the solution ?

There have been a great deal many occasions where Riot pulled a balance lever just to see the impact of a particular mechanic. In this case, the fear is how vision overall would be affected if Sightstone were pulled out of the game, and I think the solution should be to remove it, see what happens, and adjust other vision sources accordingly. If the vision game suddenly falls apart, that would show just how burdened supports are with providing vision for their teams, and the solution should be to make vision more readily available to all players, e.g. by reducing trinket cooldowns, increasing Scryer's Bloom spawns, etc.

The thing with removing Sightstone in this day and age is that it doesn't actually harm supports: in Season 3, doing so would've been terrible, because supports would go back to dedicating all of their gold and inventory for wards, but now that it's impossible to buy stealth wards in the shop, there is no way they can be forced to burden themselves with more vision than anyone else, bar some far-fetched Smite + Tracker's Knife setup (and even then, removing Tracker's Knife would solve that with minimal issues). If the real issue is that supports lose their identity as "the vision provider" (which I think is bullshit, since more often than not it's just another burden on the role), removing Sightstone would still be helpful, since it would clear the way for potentially far more interesting support vision options.

In a team game where everyone is expected to work with each other, support is pretty much the only position that truly feels like a responsibility more than anything else. Even junglers, who are expected to assist their laners with ganks and buffs, get to feel awesome about their role, because they get unparalleled freedom of movement and a wealth of strategic options right from the get-go. By contrast, supports, who already tend to be the least popular archetype in any multiplayer game, are given the strictest burdens (they _need_ to get Sightstone, plus any other mandatory item _du jour_), the least directly visible impact on the game (they can't really push or control objectives, get kills or farm, and are asked to roam alone to ward and counter-ward), and the least amount of freedom (they're expected to stick to an ally at practically all times, and only break from that when warding).

Effectively, supports are treated like servants, both by players and the developers themselves, when really they should be treated as leaders and commanders. One of the greatest fantasies of supports is that they often hold the power of life and death over their own teammates, and their plays can often influence everyone on both teams at once, and not just take one opponent out of the equation (which is a fantasy for assassins, burst mages, and some tanks). They should be the ones telling others what to do and making proactive strategic decisions, not scapegoats for the rest of their team to bully. Considering how niche supports already are across all games, they really deserve the greatest amount of pampering and privilege, not the least, and it really should not be acceptable to settle on "just fine" for them, when their lack of popularity is serious enough to have warranted large-scale changes to the game's queue system. Getting almost invariably autofilled into support is a running joke, but the very reason that is the case is because only relatively few players truly want to support, and the game can't accommodate everyone's wishes without significantly increasing queue times.

On one hand, this is true, supports really do have item scalings now, and in any case it would feel significantly more fun to pick up a proper AP or tank item, rather than a mandatory extra trinket. On the other, supports still don't scale all that well with itemization, and that's an issue that needs to be addressed, not a feature. It's already too easy for supports to feel isolated from the rest of the game, so decoupling them from item-based scaling only makes the problem worse by also excluding them from a power scaling fantasy.

A large issue with making supports scale has been that the stats used for that typically overlap with other classes, i.e. AP for caster supports and mages, and health/resists for tanks, and at this point pretty much every support, and not just Wardens (who are technically also tanks). Considering how supports are expected to work on sub-par gold and experience (also one of the reasons why they feel like a second-class role), any AP or tank item that's designed to be both slot efficient and affordable for them risks being abused by solo laners, as has happened before. Supports really need their own means of scaling, and that will likely require a new stat that specifically boosts their utility. The healing/shielding passive on some items has been a good start, but it's way too overspecialized, since defense is only a small subset of the many forms of utility supports can provide, and piling too much power onto that risks leading to excessive amounts of protection. A more general utility stat would allow supports to have much more of their kits scale, in such a way that most non-supports would likely not find items with the stat especially attractive, which would reduce overlap and abuse potential.
